Generating Documentation using Sandcastle During the Build Process

Posted by davidhayden on November 10, 2006

It took me a head-scratching 2 hours, but last night I incorporated Sandcastle in the build process to generate some decent looking documentation for a personal project. This is probably old school to many of you, but this is my first time generating any kind of documentation during the build process, let alone using Sandcastle, which is still in its September CTP stage. ( Update (11/11/2006): The November CTP was just released here )

 

 

I still have a lot of things to figure out about Sandcastle and documentation in general, but it feels good to have something generating that looks remotely close to the library developed

Since I am new to generating documentation, I must say the process seems a bit more complicated than it should be. It either is a complicated process, or I just took the naieve approach and followed the recipe posted:

  • Creating a Chm build using Sandcastle

FinalBuilder, which is a sweet build automation tool, made the process a lot easier by offering Sandcastle Actions, but I am still surprised that the recipe above calls for so many transformations. Of course, assuming the recipe is the right way, once you have it working it is pretty easy to configure for additional projects.

 

Gotchas in the Sandcastle Example

Some of the transforms, xml files, etc. for the 'test' example that downloads with Sandcastle are customized for the example. Hence you will need to change files like:

  • ReflectionToChmProject.xsl – which has the project name hardcoded in it – 'Test'
  • shared_content.xml – shared headers and footers for every html page
  • sandcastle.config – configure appopriately for your project

 

Basically I just copied and customized what I needed for inclusion into source control and used the output structure and filenames as defined in the example:

 

 

All in all a very interesting inclusion into the build process and one I need to tweak and understand better. If anyone has any tips, suggestions, recommendations, or just better or more appropriate ways to generate documentation using Sandcastle, I would love to hear any nuggets of wisdom.

by David Hayden
